name: Olympus Mons
description: The largest volcano in the Solar System, rising over 21 kilometers above the Martian surface

steps.title: Arrival at Tharsis
steps.description: Welcome to the Tharsis region — the volcanic heart of Mars. Before you rises Olympus Mons, the tallest volcano in the entire Solar System.

media.caption: Map of Tharsis Plateau with Olympus Mons location

steps.title: The Scale of a Titan
steps.description: At 21.9 kilometers high, Olympus Mons towers nearly three times taller than Mount Everest. Its base stretches 600 kilometers wide — as vast as the Hawaiian Islands combined.

media.caption: Map of Tharsis Plateau with Olympus Mons location

steps.title: The Summit Caldera
steps.description: Near the summit lies a 25-kilometer-wide, 3-kilometer-deep caldera. Each collapse here marks a chapter of volcanic eruptions that shaped this colossal Martian landscape.

scientific_significance: Reveals Mars' volcanic history and tectonic evolution

name: Valles Marineris
description: Valles Marineris is the largest canyon system in the Solar System — a colossal scar stretching more than 3,000 kilometers along Mars’ equator. It carves through the planet’s highlands like a wound from an ancient past, plunging up to 8 kilometers deep and spanning as wide as 600 kilometers. If placed on Earth, the canyon would extend from New York to Los Angeles and could swallow the entire Grand Canyon many times over. Discovered in 1971 by NASA’s Mariner 9 spacecraft, it remains one of the most breathtaking and mysterious features of the Red Planet. Scientists believe the valley was born from the stretching of Mars’ crust near the Tharsis volcanic region, later widened by landslides, erosion, and perhaps even ancient rivers. Today, Valles Marineris stands as both a monument to Mars’ violent geological history and a key to understanding whether the planet once harbored liquid water — or even life.
location: Extends from Noctis Labyrinthus in the west to chaotic terrain in the east, near the Martian equator.

facts.comparison: Ten times longer, twenty times wider, and six times deeper than Earth's Grand Canyon
facts.formation: Likely originated as a tectonic rift linked to Tharsis uplift, later shaped by collapse, erosion, and possible water flow

steps.title: Descent Over the Red Abyss
steps.description: From orbit, the vast gash of Valles Marineris dominates the Martian equator — a system of fractures stretching farther than the continental United States. As the camera descends, walls of red rock emerge from the haze. You’re looking at a canyon ten times longer than Earth’s Grand Canyon, its depths reaching nearly eight kilometers. Each layer of rock is a chapter of Martian history, exposed to the void.

media.caption: Flyover of Valles Marineris with true-color topography.
Viking Orbiter mosaic of the entire canyon system.

steps.title: Noctis Labyrinthus — The Cracked Gateway
steps.description: At the western edge lies Noctis Labyrinthus — a labyrinth of fractured valleys formed as Mars’ crust stretched and collapsed. These chaotic depressions mark the beginning of the canyon. Beneath the dust, scientists suspect volcanic and tectonic forces once tore the land apart, leaving behind a maze of cliffs and troughs that whisper of Mars’ interior stresses.

steps.title: Layers of Water and Time
steps.description: Deep within the canyon, colorful strata line the walls — evidence of ancient lakes that may have once filled these valleys. Carbonate and sulfate minerals suggest that water pooled here billions of years ago. These mineral layers are more than rocks; they are the fossilized memory of a Mars that might have been habitable. In these depths, scientists see echoes of rivers, floods, and perhaps even the chemistry of life.

steps.title: The Great Mystery
steps.description: As you rise above the entire canyon system, the full immensity of Valles Marineris unfolds — a planetary scar that may hold the story of Mars itself. Was it created by the weight of the Tharsis volcanoes? By tectonic forces, floods, or both? The truth is still hidden in its shadows. Yet one thing is clear: this canyon is not just a feature of Mars, but a monument to its restless past — and perhaps, a clue to its forgotten oceans.

media.caption: ‘Flight Through Mariner Valley’ — a visual journey across Valles Marineris.

name: Mars Polar Ice Caps
description: Dynamic regions of carbon dioxide and water ice revealing Mars' climate history

facts.composition: CO₂ dry ice dominates; water ice persists year-round
facts.seasonal_changes: CO₂ sublimates in spring, refreezes in winter

steps.title: The Frozen Crown of the North
steps.description: High above the red deserts, Mars wears a crown of ice — a dazzling polar cap stretching a thousand kilometers wide. Spiraling dark canyons twist through the frost, carved by wind and time. This is the north pole of Mars — cold, ancient, and alive.

media.caption: Map of Tharsis Plateau with Olympus Mons location

steps.title: The Chasma Boreale Rift
steps.description: Cutting across the polar ice lies Chasma Boreale — a canyon as long as Earth’s Grand Canyon and nearly two kilometers deep. Radar from Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter reveals hidden layers below the surface — frozen stories of a shifting planet.

media.caption: Map of Tharsis Plateau with Olympus Mons location

steps.title: The Breath of Carbon Dioxide
steps.description: In the spring, sunlight awakens the poles. The dry ice — frozen carbon dioxide — turns straight into gas, bursting from below and sculpting eerie shapes: spiders, starbursts, and ghostly trails. No such landscape exists on Earth.

media.caption: Map of Tharsis Plateau with Olympus Mons location

steps.title: The Slow Dance of Ice
steps.description: For fifty years, scientists searched for answers — why does Mars’ polar ice move so slowly? Now we know: gravity, wind, and the planet’s own heartbeat drive a slow, creeping flow that has shaped these poles for millions of years. The mystery endures… but the ice still whispers.

scientific_significance: Reveals climate cycles, atmospheric processes, and possible water resources

name: Cheyava Falls
description: Potential biosignature discovery in Jezero Crater showing complex organic-mineral interactions
location: Bright Angel Formation, northern rim of Neretva Vallis, Jezero Crater

facts.elements: Organic carbon, iron, sulfur, phosphorus, hydrogen

steps.title: The Lost River of Neretva Vallis
steps.description: Billions of years ago, water carved deep channels into the Martian surface. Now, in the dry bed of Neretva Vallis, the Perseverance rover searches for the faint traces of that vanished world — and the life it might have sheltered.

steps.title: The Leopard Spots of Life
steps.description: At the 'Bright Angel' formation, Perseverance drills into a rock named Cheyava Falls. Inside the sample, called Sapphire Canyon, lie minerals—vivianite and greigite—arranged in patterns scientists call leopard spots, possible fingerprints of ancient microbes.

media.caption: ‘Flight Through Mariner Valley’ — a visual journey across Valles Marineris.

steps.title: Between Science and Wonder
steps.description: The evidence is extraordinary — but not yet proof. These minerals could form without life, yet the absence of heat or acid marks deepens the mystery. In this fragment of stone, Mars may be whispering its oldest secret: that it once breathed.

scientific_significance: First detection of simultaneous organic compounds, phosphorus, and redox-sensitive minerals in lacustrine context
